Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Collaborative Research: Mobile Content Distribution in Vehicular Ad Hoc Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Mobile content distribution (MCD) is an important emerging application in vehicular ad hoc networks (VANETs). Its high and stable data rate requirement puts significant stress on the severely bandwidth-limited and highly mobile VANETs. Symbol level network coding (SLNC) provides better error-resilience and in turn higher spatial reusability for wireless transmission. It thus is a promising approach for the very bandwidth-hungry MCD networks. This project focuses on two main fundamental problems related to exploiting SLNC for MCD in VANETs. First, a theoretic study on the network capacity and performance bounds achievable by SLNC in mobile wireless networks is carried out. A new model is proposed to characterize the SLNC operation in a flow network setting. Key factors that impact the achievable throughput are identified. Methods to derive accumulated throughput for a mobile receiver following certain mobility pattern are investigated. The second research focus is on the design of distributed and localized algorithms and protocols for MCD networks using SLNC. A suite of new network protocols for SLNC-based MCD network are proposed in order to maximize the throughput of the MCD network.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Improving network capacity is a very challenging problem in multi-hop wireless networks. This project focuses on the theory and protocol design related to maximizing network throughput using novel physical layer techniques. We started with the investigation of network coding and physical layer network coding techniques. We explored the performance limit of applying physical layer network coding to improve the network throughput in mobile content distribution in vehicular ad hoc networks. We further extended our research to interference management, interference mitigation in multi-hop wireless networks. We systematically investigated interference alignment (IA) techniques, developed an analytical model for IA in multi-hop MIMO networks and designed a scheduling algorithm for MIMO Degree of Freedom (DoF) allocation in multi-hop networks. We proved the feasibility of the proposed IA model by showing that a DoF vector can be supported free of interference at the physical layer as long as it satisfies the constraints in the IA model. Based on the proposed IA model, we developed an IA design space for a multi-hop MIMO network. We proposed an efficient DoF scheduling algorithm to solve the minimum throughput maximization problem among a set of sessions and showed that our algorithm only requires local operations, and proved that the resulting DoF scheduling solution is globally feasible. Finally, we developed a single-device indoor interference localization system. The system is capable of locating interfering radios on unlicensed ISM band in indoor environments but does not require the support of pre-deployed access points. The complexity of the device is much reduced comparing to other similar techniques.

The results of our research have been widely disseminated to the wireless networks research community and we believe the results have impacted the research in this field. The graduate students involved in the project have received training in multiple areas, including wireless communications, network optimization, algorithms/protocols design, and network security.
